title: Trending: Upcycled Cosmetics, Circular Beauty - Cosmetics & Toiletries
summary: The article discusses the rising market for upcycled cosmetic ingredients, projected to grow significantly by 2031. It highlights various companies, including Kaffe Bueno, IFF, The Upcycled Beauty Company, and Hallstar France, that are developing innovative beauty products using upcycled materials. The concept of circular beauty, which emphasizes sustainability through minimal waste and recycling, is explored. Challenges in ensuring safe formulations and communicating sustainability to consumers are also mentioned.

business_innovation: TRUE - The creation and introduction of new products using upcycled ingredients represents a significant improvement over previous methods in the cosmetics industry.
green_product: TRUE - The products mentioned, such as Kaffoil-R and Faba TONIQ, are designed to reduce environmental impact by utilizing upcycled materials.
green_process: TRUE - The processes involved in upcycling cosmetic ingredients aim to reduce waste and resource consumption, fulfilling the criteria for green processes.

title: Sustainable side-stream management in Swedish food processing companies using external actors and biogas solutions - Frontiers
summary: The article discusses how food processing companies can enhance their sustainability through effective management of side-streams, focusing on upcycling bio-residuals into high-value products. It highlights the preference for using external actors for side-stream management and the special role of biogas solutions, which can help mitigate environmental impacts while improving nutrient recovery. Key findings reveal that while many companies are reactive to stakeholder demands for sustainability, some are taking a proactive stance by integrating circular economy concepts into their business models. The article calls for further research on side-stream management's role in sustainability strategies.
green_innovation: TRUE: The article describes practices in food processing companies aimed at improving sustainability by managing side-streams and reducing environmental impacts, which qualifies as green innovation.
business_innovation: TRUE: The management techniques and practices described in the article represent new or improved processes utilized by food processing companies, aligning with the definition of business innovation.
green_product: FALSE: The article does not specify a particular good or service that could be categorized as a green product.
green_process: TRUE: The article details the processes of side-stream management and biogas production in food processing companies, which are designed to minimize environmental impact and promote sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311 - Food Manufacturing, 3112 - Grain and Oilseed Milling, 3113 - Sugar and Confectionery Product Manufacturing, 3114 - Fruit and Vegetable Preserving and Specialty Food Manufacturing

title: Upcycling Initiatives Turn Railway Industry Waste Materials into Creative Products - The Japan News
summary: Railroad companies in Japan are launching upcycling and recycling initiatives to create new products from discarded materials, such as slippers from seat covers and shoehorns from old overhead wires. These efforts support a circular economy and aim to minimize waste while also attracting new fans. The products are being well-received, highlighting consumer interest in sustainable practices and the story behind the transformations. The innovations reflect a commitment to environmental sustainability in the railroad industry.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the initiatives described focus on reducing waste and promoting sustainability through upcycling discarded materials into new products, which aligns with the goals of green innovation.
business_innovation: TRUE, because the article discusses new products and business processes developed by railroad companies that significantly differ from their previous practices, representing a marked improvement in product offering and market presence.
green_product: TRUE, as the new products like slippers, shoehorns, and kettles are created from recycled materials and designed to minimize environmental impact throughout their lifecycle.
green_process: TRUE, because the manufacturing processes involved in creating these products are focused on minimizing waste and utilizing recycled materials, promoting sustainability effectively.

greenwashing: FALSE, because there is no indication that the companies are making false claims about the environmental benefits of their products; rather, they are genuinely developing and marketing upcycled products that aim to reduce waste and environmental impact.

title: Why the future of sustainable food in India is upcycling - FFOODS Spectrum - nuFFooDS Spectrum
summary: The article discusses the significant issue of food waste in India, highlighting the potential of upcycled food as a solution. It presents examples of innovative products like Nescafé Nativ Cascara and Buxton Plant+Water that utilize agricultural byproducts, reducing waste and their environmental impact. Despite a lack of awareness, consumer willingness to explore upcycled food options is high when educated about them, signaling an opportunity for growth in this sector. The Upcycled Food Association (UFA) is also promoting the upcycled economy to minimize food loss and waste across the supply chain.
green_innovation: TRUE - The innovation aligns with environmental sustainability by reducing food waste and utilizing agricultural byproducts, thereby minimizing negative environmental externalities.
business_innovation: TRUE - The creation of new upcycled food products represents a new or improved business process that differs significantly from traditional food products.
green_product: TRUE - Upcycled food products are designed to significantly reduce environmental impact by using ingredients that would otherwise go to waste.
green_process: TRUE - The process of creating upcycled food minimizes environmental impacts by utilizing side streams and reducing waste in the food supply chain.

title: what design can do reveals the 13 winners of the make it circular challenge - Designboom
summary: What Design Can Do (WDCD) announced the thirteen winners of the Make it Circular Challenge, which aims to promote circular economy practices. The competition received over 650 submissions and sought innovative solutions across various themes related to sustainability. Each winning project will receive €10,000 funding and development training to help implement their ideas effectively. The selected projects showcase diverse approaches to addressing climate challenges through circularity.
green_innovation: TRUE: The article describes innovations that aim to create a circular economy, which contributes to environmental sustainability by reducing waste and promoting the reuse of materials.
business_innovation: TRUE: The article highlights new products and processes introduced by entrepreneurs competing in the challenge, reflecting significant improvements or novel concepts in terms of functionality and sustainability.
green_product: TRUE: Many projects mentioned, such as biodegradable materials and upcycled products, are designed to reduce environmental impact throughout their life cycles, qualifying them as green products.
green_process: TRUE: These innovations often involve processes that minimize environmental impacts, such as utilizing renewable resources and promoting recycling, aligning with the definition of green processes.

title: Tortilla chips category continues to grow - Snack Food & Wholesale Bakery
summary: The tortilla chips market is experiencing significant growth, with brands innovating to provide a variety of flavors and healthier options, catering to increasing consumer demand for unique and sustainable snacks. Companies such as Frito-Lay and Beanitos are focusing on creating new products that prioritize clean ingredients, sustainability, and enhanced culinary experiences. Trends indicate a shift towards plant-based, upcycled, and lower-impact ingredients in response to consumer preferences for health and environmental values. Notable innovations in the tortilla chip category include chickpea-based chips and offerings that embrace environmentally responsible sourcing and manufacturing processes.

title: Q&A: Carbonwave expands seaweed emulsifier as demand grows - CosmeticsDesign.com USA
summary: Carbonwave secured a $5 million investment to expand its production of SeaBalance 2000, a seaweed-based cosmetic emulsifier derived from Sargassum. This upcycled product has gained significant interest for its sustainable and multifunctional properties in the cosmetics industry. The innovation aims to replace petroleum-based emulsifiers while addressing waste and environmental concerns linked to Sargassum. By utilizing this abundant and renewable resource, Carbonwave is contributing to both environmental sustainability and the development of the cosmetics sector.
green_innovation: TRUE - This is green innovation as SeaBalance 2000 is derived from upcycled Sargassum, significantly reducing environmental impacts, replacing synthetic ingredients, and promoting sustainability within the cosmetics industry.
business_innovation: TRUE - It is a business innovation because SeaBalance 2000 is a new and improved product introduced to the market that significantly differs from traditional emulsifiers.
green_product: TRUE - SeaBalance 2000 meets the definition of a green product because it is designed and manufactured to significantly reduce environmental impact through the upcycling of Sargassum.
green_process: TRUE - This represents a green process as it employs sustainable techniques for extracting and formulating the product, minimizing waste and environmental impacts.

title: Singapore's Confetti Snacks in talks with Walmart and Target as collaboration with Dole and Disney lays on the horizon - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: Confetti, a company that upcycles surplus crops and 'ugly veggies' into snacks, has secured significant retail partnerships and plans to expand in both the US and Asia-Pacific markets. They emphasize local sourcing and are collaborating with Dole to create vegan dips, while also introducing a themed product line featuring Disney characters. The company has seen a year-on-year growth rate of 50% and is exploring new flavors beyond vegetable chips to further reduce food waste.
green_innovation: TRUE: Confetti's innovation involves upcycling surplus crops and 'ugly veggies', which contributes to reducing food waste and promotes environmental sustainability by utilizing ingredients that might otherwise be discarded.
business_innovation: TRUE: Confetti's introduction of new snack products, particularly those made from upcycled ingredients, represents a significant change in their product offerings, fulfilling the definition of business innovation.
green_product: TRUE: The vegetable and mushroom chips produced by Confetti are designed to reduce environmental impact by using upcycled ingredients, fitting the definition of green products.
green_process: TRUE: The manufacturing process used by Confetti, which focuses on upcycling and minimizing waste, promotes sustainability and reduces environmental impacts, adhering to the definition of a green process.

title: Tiger breaks beer-making boundaries to keep up with 'sessionable and accessible' drinking trends - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: Tiger has launched a new product, Tiger Soju Infused Lager, inspired by K-culture drinking trends, which features two flavors and an accessible taste profile. The product aims to appeal to a wider consumer base and reflects the company's commitment to innovation. Tiger is also engaging big names like G-DRAGON for brand promotion and hosted a festival celebrating the launch. The company emphasizes its Asian heritage and aims to push the boundaries of beer.
